section.title: Configuring and Building Draco
section.para: The Draco Build System is based on GNU AUTOCONF and MAKE. We have endeavored to follow the GNU Coding Standards while designing the build system. (See Stallman, R. Gnu coding standards.) For more details on the configure/make model of code development, see Free Software Foundation, 1996.
The basic steps to build Draco are the following:

section.para: The following sections will sho how to configure and build Draco using the DBS. For beginners, the easiest way to start may be to persue the examples section, Example Builds.

section.title: Compiling and Installing Draco
section.para: Having configured Draco, compiling and installing is straightforward.

The MAKE optional variable nj is used to specify the number of processors to use for the compiling/linking step. MAKE runs different targets depending upon the directory level at which it is run. Running MAKE under $BUILD will actually do a compile + install for each Draco package sitting in $DRACO/src. After this make is run, the following directores will exist:

The first thing that MAKE does when it is run in $BUILD is install tools into the $INSTALL/libexec directory. These tools are necessary for subsequent operations; thus, MAKE must be run in $BUILD before any other compile tasks are performed. Alternatively, one could run make install in $BUILD/tools to install the tools.

After the tools are installed, MAKE will enter each $BUILD/src/pkg directory and do a compile + install. The pkg subdirectories are entered in the appropriate order automatically (this order is actually specified in draco.ac) to ensure that dependencies are preserved. The stpes from a MAKE in $BUILD are as follows:

enter $BUILD/src/pkg in order and do a make install

section.para: Thus, running MAKE in $BUILD or $BUILD/src actually does a make install in each subdirectory. Running MAKE in the subdirectores does a build (compile) of the package directory's principle targets.
The targets for each package directory in Draco are:

section.para: The targets are determined by the package configure .ac file. Generating this file is the subject of Adding a Package to Draco. By default, the executable will be the package name. The library will have the name lib${LIB_PREFIX}package. The LIB_PREFIX variable can be set at configure time, see Configure Options. By default, LIB_PREFIX is set to rtt_. For example, the dss++ package will produce a library called librtt_ds++.a(so). As described above, libraries are installed in $INSTALL/lib, headers in $INSTALL/include/pkg, and executables in $INSTALL/bin. Draco libbraries have a custom prefix to prevent name clashes between system libraries and Draco libraires.

The DBS allows the definitions of custom targets through inclusion of a Makefile.target file. Sources for the build can also be customized using a Makefile.source file. Finally, a Makefile.misc file can be created for nearly any miscellaneous purpose. See section Draco Build System Reference Manual for details on customizing the configure/make environment.

section.para: Two items should be noted from this table. First, doxygen documentation is not generated by default. One must run make autodoc from $BUILD or make from $BUILD/autodoc. Second, the unit tests are run using the make check command. Unit tests can be run recursively from any directory level. For example, to run every package's unit tests, run make check from $BUILD. To run the c4 package unit tests, run make check from $BUILD/src/c4 or $BUILD/src/c4/test. More detail is given on the unit testing support in Build System Architecure.

In each directory, MAKE is run recursively. For example, running make inside of $BUILD/src will do a compile + install in each $BUILD/src subdirectory. However, it will not install the tools in $BUILD/tools. One must run make in $BUILD or make install in $BUILD/tools to install the tools.

section.section:
Draco Packages and Vendors
Draco packages co-exist according to the priciples of Levelized Software Design (Lakos, J. Large-Scale C++ Software Design. 1996). The current hierarchy of Draco packages is as follows: ***
The Draco levelized architecture has significance for clients. Clients wishing to use a high-level package must also include the following libraries (packages) at link time:
-lrtt_mc -lrtt_viz -lrtt_meshReaders -lrtt_traits -lrtt_rng -lrtt_c4 -lrtt_ds++
Notice that mc depends on traits through its association with the viz package. Likewise, a Draco package utilizing mc will also have these addiotional packages as dependencies, whether it utilizes them directly or not.
As mentioned before, some Draco packages also rely on external vendors. The vendor dependency can be optional or required. For example, c4 uses MPI; however, it can be compiled in a serial mode that does not require MPI. The following table lists the Draco pakcages that have external vendor requitements:

To use and test a package that requires a vendor, the vendor libraries must be included at link time. Some packages (rng for instance) will not build at all if the vendor is not specified during the Draco build. Secion Configure Options shows how to tell Draco where vendor libraries and included files are located.
External clients must remember to include vendor libraries when loading Draco libraries. Returing to the mc package example, the rng package uses the c4 package may use MPI; thus, the total link line should be:
-lrtt_mc -lrtt_viz_meshReaders -lrtt_traits -lrtt_rng -lrtt_c4 -lrtt_ds++ -lmpi
The DBS automatically includes these vendor libraries; thus, if the Draco DBS is imported into client applications, these dependences wil be taken care of automatically. See section Importing the Draco Build System for details.
The Draco parallel communication package, c4 (namespace rtt_c4), can be built serial or parallel as diescribed in Confgure Options. The inclusion of c4 services into a package makes the package parallel Thus, running tests or applications with packages that depend on c4 will require the use of mpirun or whatever system-dependent machinations are required to run a parallel executable. The DBS automatically uses parallel execution semantics on packages that depend on c4.

section.title: Configure Options
section.para: The DBS provides multiple configure options that can be used to tailor the resuting build process. For convenience, we divide these options into three general categories: build options, vendor options, and Draco vendor options. The Draco vendor options are only required when importing the DBS into a client; thus, discussion of these configure options is deferred until section Importing the Draco Build System. Additionally, all of the standard configure options exist although not all of them have meaning in the DBS. To get a list of configure options, run configure with the option --help:
This command produces a list of options with descriptions. The options after the heading " --enable " and " --with options recognized: " are defined by the DBS.

We have already seen one option recognized by the DBS, --prefix. This option tells the DBS where to install Draco. In the DBS we use --enable options for binary switches and --with options for specifying an option. Configure options on the form --with have default behacior, default values for a given option (when the option's values are unspecified), and valid argumnts for a gicen otion. section.para: Finally, there is another set of configure options that allow additional values to be added to Makefile flags. These options are:

These flags are used as a stopgap measure on new or unpredictable systems. In general, only Draco developers and architects will use these options. See Draco Build System Reference Manual for more details on Makefile variables in the DBS. These flags may also be used for specialized compiles (e.g.: profiling, coverage analysis, etc.).

As described in Draco Packages and Vendors, many Draco packages have external vendor requirements. If configure is not given any options, Draco will look for vendors in default compiler/linker locations and the LD_LIBRARY_PATH. These usually are /usr/lib, /lib, etc. If the vendor libraries and includes exist in a non-common location, by which we mean a space that the compiler/linker will not find by default, then configure must be told the location of the vendor libraries and/or include files.
The general pattern for most vendor options is:
section.programlisting: --with-<vendor> # vendor options --with-<vendor>-inc # location of include files --with-<vendor>-lib # location of library files
section.para: Of course, not all vendors have include or library locations. Additionally, specifying an include or library path will override any default search paths or locations specified by LD_LIBRARY_PATH. The LANL ASCI machines utilize modules to define many packages. The modules will place necessary include/library files into common locations or a defined LK_LIBRARY_PATH. Thus, it is (usually) not necessary to specify the following options on ASCI machines:

section.para: The LAPACK options should only be overridden if the client wishes to use ATLAS instead of the vendor implementations of LAPACK and BLAS.

note.para: Trilinos depends on the availability of LAPACK or ATLAS on the current machine for this build. Thus, if Trilinos is specified on the configure line, then you must also specify the location for LAPACK.

ASCI White uses scripts for compilers, newmpxIC for MPI-based builds and newxIC for serial builds. If the default ASCI White compiler is used, then setting MPI include or library paths will result in link-time errors. Also, do not use cache (-C) when configuring on ASCI White.

section.para: We wish to install Draco in /home/joe/draco-debug. The Draco source is checked out in /home/joe/draco. Use ATLAS for BLAS/LAPACK. Here are the steps:
